title: What technology has not improved for several decades? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sewing needle  The first form of sewing was probably tying together animal skins using thorns and sharpened rocks as needles, with animal sinew or plant material as thread . A point that might be from a bone needle dates to 61,000 years ago and was discovered in Sibudu Cave, South Africa. Iron sewing needles were found at the Oppidum of Manching, dating to the third century BC. The next major break-through in needle-making was the arrival of high-quality steel-making technology from China in the tenth century. This technology later extended to Germany and France, although not significantly in England. England began creating needles in 1639 at Redditch[1].  Paper Clip  The first patent for a bent wire paper clip was awarded in the United States to Samuel B. Fay, in 1867. This clip was originally intended primarily for attaching tickets to fabric, although the patent recognized that it could be used to attach papers together[2].  Safety Pin  American mechanic Walter Hunt is the inventor of the safety pin. It included a clasp that covered the point and kept it from opening, and a circular twist at the bend to act as a spring and hold it in place. Charles Rowley (Birmingham, England) independently patented a similar safety pin in October 1849[3].  Spoon  Preserved examples of various forms of spoons used by the ancient Egyptians include those composed of ivory, flint, slate and wood; many of them carved with religious symbols. The earliest English reference appears to be in a will of 1259. The modern form, with the tip of the bowl narrower than the base and the rounded end of the handle turned down, came into use about 1760[4]. Footnotes[1] Sewing needle - Wikipedia[2] Paper clip - Wikipedia[3] Safety pin - Wikipedia[4] Spoon - Wikipedia

A one-time fantastic invention which has advanced considerably from the first stone or wooden ones. So, all technologies and inventions will be improved upon until some point when solid matter is transcended by a very advanced species. They have the ability to think or wish anything into being and out of being (using the acme of tech, of course); they can travel instantaneously from one side of the universe to the next, from one universe to another; from one time or dimension to another - they’re basically gods. At their level I’m guessing that matter no longer holds any attractions, and that more important things preoccupy them, if anything preoccupies them. I can only imagine that they are like buddhas and beyond, if that’s possible. How’s this scenario: The beings described above, having gone through the whole matter process with all its suffering and eons-long trek upward - this happened over the course of a billion or more years previous to our time (it might even have happened prior to the formation of our universe) - became buddhas and saw that new sentient beings were emerging and would have to go through the same painful process they did, so they sent a few buddhas to each world to help us get to where they are.

Although the question is a bit vague in using the words “changed much” and a lot depends on what one considers a “change” and how much change is “much”, arguably the following technologies qualify per some defensible interpretation of those terms. Some of these technologies have had significant “add-ons” since they were invented, like digital control systems for metal-cutting lathes, or improved materials, but the underlying technology of how metal cutting is accomplished hasn’t changed much since it was first invented. phonographs piston steam engines metal cutting lathes/mills paper lead pencils toner-based copiers solid rocket motors combines looms kinetic energy driven electric generators (as opposed to solar cells or fuel cells, or thermo-electric based electricity generation) That should be enough of a list off the top of my head.

Here are some technologies which are still useful after nearly 2000 years:  Senatus Populus Qver Romanus (SPQR) - inscription on an triumphal arch erected in 81 CE by the Emperor Domitian.  Semi-cursive Chinese ideograms from “Preface to the Poems Composed at the Orchid Pavilion”, CE 353 Alphabets are most durable of technologies. They must remain the same to stay legible and therefore useful. They can last indefinitely. Ordinary machines are easily displaced when new materials or techniques come along. These abstract and arbitrary shapes can be used even after the language they express is gone. We are nothing like the Romans. We dress differently, build our houses differently, and don’t even eat the same way. But we still use their letterforms! This most insubstantial of inventions is the one that lasts the longest.
